S4.T1.caption: Table 1:  The number of sentences whose length does not change using specific prompts and not using specific prompts on different data sets
references: For the sentences to be corrected in the test set, we use the prompt of the input sentence in the few-shot prompt to construct the same prompt for the sentences to be corrected in the testset and then enter LLMs to hope that the LLMs will correct the spelling of the error corrected sentences through in-context learning. Considering the length limit of LLMs on the length of the input (including historical dialogue), and the deterioration of the semantic understanding of LLMs with long input lengths. Before spell-checking each sentence, we clear the historical memory of the LLMs and add our few-shot prompt. In order to verify that the prompt we proposed is effective, we counted the number of sentences whose length remained unchanged before and after using a specific prompt and not using a specific prompt. The results are in Table 1. Experiments were performed using the API of GPT-3.5-Turbo.

S5.T2.caption: Table 2:  Statistical information regarding the dataset in our experiments, which includes the total count of sentences (#Sent), the average length of these sentences (Avg. Length), and the total number of spelling mistakes (#Errors).
references: Datasets: In the evaluation of CSC task, we use two highly used datasets. The first, SIGHAN15 Tseng et al. (2015), consists of handwritten samples from learners of Chinese as a Second Language (CSL). These samples provide a rich source of real-world language usage by non-native speakers, offering insights into common errors and patterns in learning Chinese. The second dataset Lv et al. (2023) is specialized and segmented into three distinct domains to provide a more comprehensive understanding of language use in specific contexts. For the LAW domain, data is sourced from the stems and choices of multiple-choice questions in judicial examinations, reflecting the formal and technical language of the legal field. The MED domain encompasses data from question-and-answer pairs drawn from online medical consultations, showcasing the specific terminology and communication style in healthcare. The ODW (Official Document Writing) domain includes data from various official documents such as news, policies, and state reports on national conditions, representing formal and structured writing styles. The statistics of the test data from these four datasets we used are shown in Table 2.

S5.T3.caption: Table 3:  The performance of all baselines and RS-LLMs. RS-gpt-3.5-turbo means RS-LLM on gpt-3.5-turbo and RS-glm-3-turbo means RS-LLM on glm-3-turbo. The glm-3-turbo and gpt-3.5-turbo utilizing identical few-shot prompts as RS-LLM, but without semantic information.
references: Table 3 shows the evaluation results of our RS-LLM against other models on the SIGHAN15, LAW, MED and ODW test sets. We found that the experimental results of LLM have certain fluctuations with temperature changes, so our baseline experiments of LLM and RS-LLM experiments on the same model all use the same temperature. It is observed that our RS-LLM outperforms all baselines on all metrics in most cases for all datasets. In particular, LLM uses the same few-sample cues as RS-LLM but does not add semantic information when performing the CSC task. The experimental results of this paper verify the effectiveness and superiority of LLM semantic information in CSC tasks.

A1.T4.caption: Table 4:  The performance of different In-context Learning approaches added in prompts on LLMs. RS-gpt-3.5-turbo means RS-LLM on gpt-3.5-turbo and RS- glm-3-turbo means RS-LLM on glm-3-turbo.
references: Fig.4 and Fig.5 show the evaluation results of our RS-LLM and LLM with different context learning methods. For specific experimental results, see the table 4 in the appendix 5. From Fig.4 and Fig.5, we find that the performance of the CSC task on LLM improves on most datasets as the number of examples in the context increases, both in terms of detection and correction. Furthermore, RS-LLM is more effective than LLM in few-shot scenarios compared to zero-shot and one-shot scenarios. Such experimental results reflect the effectiveness of our in-context learning approach designed for CSC task.

A1.T5.caption: Table 5:  The performance of different semantic information is added to few-shot prompts on LLMs. ’拼音’ means phonetic information, ’部首’ means radical information, ’结构’ means structural information, ’笔画’ means strokes information.
references: In order to further study the impact of semantic information on LLMs when performing CSC tasks. We design to use phonetic information, radical information, structural information and strokes information. Each of these four types of information is added to our zero-shot prompt, one-shot prompt, and few-shot prompt. To explore the impact of these four prompts on the test set of SIGHAN15, LAW, MED, and ODW in three different contexts of learning. The specific experimental results is Table 5 in Appendix 5.
